text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on April 19 in history:
1587 - English admiral Sir Francis Drake entered Cadiz harbour and sank the Spanish fleet, an action he referred to "as singeing the king of Spain's beard".
1588 - Paolo Veronese, one of the major painters of the 16th century Venetian school, died.
1689 - Queen Christina of Sweden died. Queen from 1644-54, she abdicated because of her secret conversion to Roman Catholicism, which was proscribed in Sweden.
1713 - Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI issued the Pragmatic Sanction, giving women the rights of succession to Hapsburg possessions.
1775 - The American War of Independence began with the defeat of the British under Thomas Gage at Lexington and Concord.
1824 - English poet Lord Byron died of a fever while aiding Greek rebels fighting the Turks.
1839 - The Treaty of London was signed, establishing recognition of the Kingdom of Belgium by all the states of Europe.
1850 - The Clayton-Bulwer agreement was signed by which Britain and the U.S. agreed not to obtain exclusive control of a proposed Panama canal.
1853 - Russia claimed protectorate over Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1881 - Benjamin Disraeli, British statesman and twice prime minister (1868 and 1874-80), died.
1882 - Charles Darwin, English naturalist who developed the theory of evolution expressed in "The Origin of Species by Means of Natural Selection", died.
1906 - Pierre Curie, French chemist and physicist, was run over and killed in Paris. Together with his wife, Marie, he had worked on magnetism and radioactivity.
1927 - U.S. actress Mae West was found guilty of indecent behaviour in her Broadway production "Sex".
1933 - President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued a proclamation removing the U.S. from the gold standard.
1943 - Polish Jews rose up in the Warsaw ghetto in a failed rebellion against the Nazis.
1956 - Prince Rainier of Monaco married U.S. film actress Grace Kelly.
1960 - A student uprising toppled the authoritarian government of South Korean President Syngman Rhee.
1966 - An advance party of 4,500 Australian troops left Sydney to fight alongside U.S. troops in Vietnam.
1967 - The unmanned U.S. spacecraft Surveyor 3 landed on the moon.
1967 - Konrad Adenauer, West German statesman and chancellor (1949-63), died. He had followed a policy of partnership with NATO and the European customs union in rebuilding West Germany.
1971 - Sierra Leone became a republic within the Commonwealth.
1971 - Russia launched its space station Salyut into earth's orbit.
1979 - In the Central African Empire, 150 children were massacred at the Ngaragba prison.

1989 - British novelist Daphne du Maurier died. Among the world's best-selling authors for half a century, her period romances and adventure stories include "Jamaica Inn", "Rebecca" and "Frenchman's Creek".
1989 - Forty-seven crewmen died in an explosion on the U.S. battleship USS Iowa during Atlantic manoeuvres.
1993 - More than 80 Branch Davidians were killed when federal agents stormed their compound in Waco, Texas after a 51-day standoff.
1994 - Somali gunmen kidnapped Sudan's envoy to Somalia in a notorious Mogadishu district where inter-clan fighting had raged for four days.
1995 - A huge car bomb tore apart a federal building in Oklahoma City, the death toll eventually reaching 168.
